Alright, so after 14 hours of very enjoyable play, I've decided it's time to write a review.

This is going to be a fairly lengthy, very technical and detailed look at the game, from the perspective of an ex-Runescape player. If you played Runescape in the past, and are interested in nitty gritty mechanical details, then this review will be for you. I'm going to be comparing pretty much everything to how Runescape did things.

TL;DR: Hands down recommended 100% to any ex-Runescape members. This game is overall absolutely fantastic, and I've just been filled with so much excitement and joy and nostalgia, on top of the fact that this game is better than Runescape in a lot of ways.

Rather than Runescape where you have all of your skills mixed up on one tab, here your skills are sorted between two tabs: Gathering and Crafting.

For Gathering, you have: Fishing, Skinning, Farming, Foraging, Forestry, Prospecting, and Crystal Cutting.

For Crafting, you have: Cooking, Leatherworking, Tailoring, Alchemy, Weaponsmithing, Armorsmithing, and Jewelry.

There is indeed a Skinning skill. Rather than RS where you kill a cow and it drops hide and a perfect little red and white steak, now you actually need a knife and can skin your animals, which will give you those, and skin as well. Very enjoyable difference.

Smithing has been split up into Armorsmithing and Weaponsmithing. This makes sense and from a gameplay/economy perspective, promotes people to specialize in one or the other. I enjoy the change.

Forestry is Woodcutting. Prospecting is Mining which includes smelting, rather than RS where smelting was considered part of Smithing. Foraging is what it sounds like, all different kinds of gathering, from apples to various plants which are used in alchemy. In RS, Herbalism was a combination of gathering herbs and alchemy.

reviewText:
This game is good, but by no means excellent.

I've been playing since release and was a beta tester for a little bit (but some have been testing a lot longer than i).

What this game really is a disguised pay to play game.

If you look at the subscription you'll understand why.

You have to unlock certain components for a character, and if you do not want to have all of those things right away, it will take some time to be able to access (if you're slowly gathering ep [in game currency bought with cash]) or being a hardcore trader able to make the sales.

the limitation for a f2p player is a bit harsh, but if you can find a way to unlock the the character limitations then it's no problem. It's how you will do it will be either a pain or not.

The leveling can get a bit slow at times, especially when you run out of quests (which you will at some points) and have to grind mobs or run dungeons according to your level.

non combat skills are great. the game dialogue and story are very, well written.

Certain aspects about combat need to be addressed, but it's ultimately how smart you are with every thing that dictates how well you do in a team fight (but 1v1 some classes will just eat you if you're not with out help)

The lack of environment expansion (in regards to size and the camera angle) make the maps a little squishes and the mob spawn rate can seem a bit over whelming at times, but it's nothing you can handle.

The big thing i like about eldevin is that it adds a bit of suspense when leveling solo. You almost always need to be on your toes (at least for less armored people) and have pots available, or a side kick.

This game is very deserving of the 2013 best f2p mmo awar that it was given.

If you play this game hardcore, you will get bored and frustrated.

This is not world of warcraft, and is even less of a design clone from it too.

But, it's fun.

8.5/10

Big ups and good luck.

I do not recommend this game because it has deteriorated into vanity updates for money. Mainly with half baked releases of content, such as a barely there guild system. Their development cycle for any content is massive and hunted cow studios interaction with the community is very limited.

A lot of the player base left for numerous reasons and when they first released on steam their population increased due to curious people. This did not last and they rapidly lost the new people who checked the game out.  Getting dungeons on the small player base is very hard.  On average you are talking 100 odd players over 3 servers and they are mainly the hardcore holdouts that are left hoping. They use a lot of asset reskins to put out vanity. This game if you were to play, get to know the small pop and hope to find someone willing to let you tag along on dungeons.

They have also some solo dungeons, but mysteriously have stopped them after a certain point even though the population is not there.  For instance on other mmorpg games from what I have played, you have varied options to dungeon and find gear with smaller groups and decent gear. Here they limit your gem finding abilities and gear and almost make you feel ashamed you were forced to go solo. Then after a while you don't have the solo dungeon option as stated. Five man dungeons are the model really and at a certain point, you will need to try to get into them. The queue system is a no go, you can queue there for days, they will never fill. You need to find a group through people you know or chat hopefully.

The game could do with more listening to the community and a big injection of development staff and more content options.

If you look at the servers, us or eu, These are the ones to go too with a hand full usually online. The third server is empty virtually and just used for farming items.  Pvp island you can gather on. The pvp zone is pretty light on players, but will have a few who like to troll the gathers and kill them as they try to collect items here. I can only assume the island was so devoid of people the developers at one point decided to add nodes for crafters to come collect there to be targets to satisfy pvpers. You can gather outside of course in safe areas at a slower rate. But one can hazard a guess if so they wished why they want crafters on the pvp island.

The questing is pretty much standard. Kill x amount of creatures, hand in quest, get xp or item. Can you give this item to someone for me, you run off hand in. Can you kill x amount of this creature until they drop x amount of items so I can have them, go gather then return for xp. Stuff like that.

Unless you made friends be prepared for the roadblock at the end as you need dungeons for end gear or I guess buy the materials.

I think that covers most aspects of the game, I will briefly discuss the crafting, you basically gather or buy a rake of materials and take them to crafting stations plant character there and have them work away until the mats are gone. You either go gather more materials then or buy more.

Guilds are bare bones and pvp maps limited and very few playing. No auction house either and it is almost 2016, really mind blowing to even have to type that. There is a subscription payment option also if you want faster exp gain etc and some eldevin points monthly. Check the hcs store for pricing.

On a finishing note if you do play. Gold will come easy later in game so do not panic. Eldevin is the currency you buy from other players or hunted cow studios and is far rarer. It is a paid for currency with very limited ways to get it, maybe at end game harvesting gems and selling them to other players for eldevin points. Dungeons give the most easy access to get gems. But you need those dungeon runs, some will get them, others not so muc.

Overall, I will say this game should still be in beta and should never have been released for so long without basics in place. But it was released and I reviewed it as a finished product. They need to refocus as a dev team and get away from vanity releases and back to proper content. If you disagree with my review, feel free.  But it is my point of view and I ask you just respect that. It is my opinion. You can play or have played and feel differently.

PVP – Most new players coming here ask about PVP.  PVP is dead, it is broken and virtually non existent in this game.  There is one small open PVP map in the game called Trappers Atoll, TA.  Here players can enter starting at level 15.  They have not tiered the map at all.  Max level 45 players freely roam this tiny map freely killing players who are 30 levels lower then they are.  It is pretty much the only thing a level 45 can do besides run the final dungeon again for fun at end game.
There are standard 4 on 4 PVP matches that last 10 minutes assuming you can find 8 people to join.  Again the matches are not tiered and you have a 15 and a 45 level in the same match.  Nothing about it I would call PVP.  Again, this is both true in the PVP map and the PVP matches.  Both of them are not tiered.  It is not just the bullying but having someone who played the game over a year with the best gear and best weapons and best gems in the same area as someone who played the game for 4 hours, come on really????????

Graphics – The game is a browser game.  It is closest to Runescape with a tad better graphics. If you want eye candy for your new super charged machine look elsewhere.  I personally do not care about graphics, my first PC game was civ 1 by Sid Meirs in grade school to give you an example here.  I know that other people now a days do care.

Sound – Again same as graphics.

Characters – The game states to be classless.  I have found that it is really worse then having a fixed class.  All of your talents and spells and stats are based off of the primary weapon you will use throughout the game.  If you pick up a bow and start to use a bow you will only pick talents and spells that uses a bow.  If you want to say play a ranger and use bows and swords you will be out of luck. Then there is the 2-hand weapon guy, the 2 1-hand weapon guy, the 1-hand sword and shield guy and finally your mage.
There is not really much variety here, level 45 player builds all look the same with no variety.

Crafting / Professions there are 14 and you can learn any of them and max them out at level 45.
Please note that currently there is no mailbox or auction house and the populaton on servers drops down to as low as 30 during slow periods of the night.  So if you are thinking of crafting or gathering to raise gold it it pretty much pointless at this time.

Quests – The standard go fetch x items, go talk to this npc here, run around the map back and forth.  Again nothing new here.  I got really tired of the run from this city to the other city, talk to a NPC then run back.  Only to find that as soon as you complete that quest the same NPC has you run to the same city you just came from to talk to another NPC 2 feet away.

Pay to Win – Not really.  The only bad downside is the fact that there are things here to buy with real cash that are not available for a free to play player.  The worse example is the backpack.  A free to play player can buy and upgrade bags costing thousands of gold pieces for a normal bag each.  A backpack, which holds about twice or three times the best bag a free to play player still costs over $15 in real money to buy.  Also note that you can have multiple bags in both your inventory and in the bank.  There is also no way to extract / upgrade gems except for using real money.  So keep in mind if you put a gem in a slot it will cost real money if you want to use it later on or upgrade it to the next level. There is a cap on gold for free to play players and with a subscription it is removed.  Also a subscriber earns 2x as many relics when running a dungeon so they get the best gear twice as fast.
Finally a subscriber will earn an extra 25% more gold from loot drops and when they sell items to a vendor.

Loyalty program – What a joke.  You earn 5 tokens a day when you log in.  Then you can turn these points in for free stuff.  Let me give you an example of what they want to reward you with.  For 10 loyalty tokens you can buy a little bit of copper.  Copper is the first metal you can mine in the game, it is found all over the entire map and the amount you get for free you can mine in less then 1 minute on the map.  If the intention is to keep players coming back to play they failed miserably here.

Dungeons – You get a new dungeon every 5 levels except for level 30.  The best gear and loot drops from them.  They have opened a can of worms here as well.  There are 2 ways to run a dungeon.  If you have a full party of 5 you can run the dungeon in dungeon mode like a standard mmo dungeon.  However, they also have a story mode where as little as 1 player can enter and do the same dungeon with the monsters being 1/5 health and fewer of them and the loot drop greatly reduced. So now it is almost impossible to get a full dungeon party together because at any time a single player can just run through the dungeon and not have to wait.  You also have a few problems with groups of 5 players speed running the dungeons in story mode to just farm the bosses for relics getting the best gear that way.  There is also a loot system where players can pass, greed or need items that drop.  This creates all sorts of head aches as some players will need on everything and have a better chance to win the loot rolls and they get kicked out quick.
Another problem with story mode is players never learn how to play and run dungeons with other players.  At end game and the hardest dungeons, where team work is key to victory, these players have no clue how to work together.

Mounts – Yes they have horses and other things to ride here.  As soon as you have 6 gold you can buy the first level ride skill for 5 gold and a flying disc for 1 gold.

There is no mail system or auction house in game.  It may or may not be coming sometime in the future.  This means the only way to trade items is to spam world chat and hope that the one player who may buy/sell you something is on at the same time you are.  It makes crafting and gathering to make gold rather pointless since chances are pretty good no one on will be buying that one thing.
This is kind of hard to do when the player base drops to as low as 30 players actually online during the slow periods of the night. The highest I have seen on at one time during my time here is 800 on a weekend during the christmas break when all of the students were out of school.  I understand that the staff is tiny they have more games to support then developers currently.  It is easy to check how many players are on.  Just type /who in chat line and it gives you the number.

I tired to cover everything you might want to learn about the game before playing it yourself.
At this time of writing I put in just over 400 game hours, my character was max level, all of my quests were done and I have run all dungeons at least once.  Now I choose to leave instead of going to TA and killing brand new players so hopefully some of them will stay past level 15 and play the game.

reviewText:
You might have noticed that this review is long. Very long. Before you start reading the next one, I have a TL;DR and Pros and Cons for if you're too lazy to read the whole thing:

TL;DR: I wouldn't rate this game very high. A 7/10 at most. Still, it's fun if the few cons don't bother you.

Pro:
- A very nice storyline. Maybe not very original, but definitely engaging.
- Not a lot of paid content. Most content is accessible without having to pay real money.
- Very large world.
- A bunch of cool dungeons that you can beat solo as well as in a group.
- A lot of the armour looks really cool and original.
- The UI looks very good.

Con:
- A bit unoriginal as an MMO.
- A lot of (mostly vanity) items are very, VERY expensive, either in real life or ingame currency.
- Armour can not be worn as vanity. No matter how cool it looks, once its outdated you can't show it off anymore.
- At least in my opinion, the look of the game is not very good. The graphics seem old and the aesthetics are nothing great either.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Eldevin. Your average MMO, to be honest. It doesn't really have a lot to separate it from the crowd; This being both a good and a bad thing.
For example, if you're used to other MMOs, it's probably very easy to get in to. But on the other side, why would you, since it's not very different from said MMOs? Well, it of course has *some* elements that most others don't have. For one, the percentage of content you have to pay for to be able to use is very low. The little bit of paid content it does have is also mostly (if not all) vanity stuff, and no entire areas of the map that you have to pay $29,99 for to unlock. So, there's that for a difference with most other MMOs.

The world is very large, but most of it isn't accessible until you're a higher level. Well, it is accessible of course, but not recommended. Most mobs are aggressive, so it's difficult to survive in higher leveled areas.

The different skills, talents and classes allow for a bunch of different play styles, but quests and sometimes even the storyline will force you to use specific skills and thus upgrade them even if you wouldn't really need them except for those few quests.

There's a bunch of 'group instances' throughout the game. They all have their own loot, which includes cool-looking armour sets, weapons, etc. They can be beat in Story Mode (single player, no loot gotten, mainly for quickly doing story quests) and Group Mode (multiplayer, loot divided between group members, all mobs get buffs to be challenging for 5-player groups).

I've seen some complaints about the look of the game and yeah, I agree. The graphics look old to me. While without a doubt some like it, I think it makes the game look outdated. Nor the characters nor the terrain have much detail, and just look like something your average game in 2003 could best. The aesthetics aren't great either. The characters move a bit rigid (which is something we see a lot, though). Of course this is understandable because Eldevin isn't some big super blockbuster AAA 300 million dollar game but still. The UI looks good, though. With a lot of small games you see that the UI is just a bunch of grey, half-transparent squares with numbers or text in Times New Roman, but the UI in Eldevin looks very nice.

There's maybe not very many different vanity items compared to other games that have just been out for much longer, but there's enough to make each player that has invested some time in the game look different from eachother. A lot of the vanity is (once again) very, very expensive. Either in the sense that it costs a lot of real life money (not very common in this game but it happens) or a lot of ingame money. For example the vanity bought with Prestige Points. Prestige Points are earned by doing some daily quests around the game. Players who have 'just' started playing will get 4 per day at most, more experienced players will get around 10 if they do their best. During Christmas you can get much more (>100 per day is possible, but you'll have to grind christmas mobs for hours). Even then, they're SO EXPENSIVE. One vanity set costs (I think) 50,000 prestige points. I might be horribly wrong, but at this scale, it doesn't matter much. That's why the costs of most vanity items are my main (but almost my only) complaint.
I could name more examples and rant about it for hours but I'm already writing a bit too much. So yeah.

reviewText:
Amazing Experience!
This game is great, and I've thoroughly enjoyed my experienc thusfar and will continue to play hopefully for a long while.

First of all, this game hits that nostalgia factor, as at times it can feel somewhat like runescape. This is mostly due to the different skills and professions you can get yourself into, such as mining, making weapons, leatherwork, cooking, fishing, jewlery making, and much more. It feels nostalgic and rewarding to level up skills that tie in with your play style in order to provide for yourself and sell/supply to others.

_________________________________
--Overview--
Pros:
In-Depth storyline
Many skills/professions to become skilled in
Great community
Enjoyable sidequests
Diverse world
Great for playing in a group
Cons:
Dwindling playerbase
Outdated graphics (Not a con for me personally, as I find the grapics charming, though many people want better graphics._______________________________

Premium CurrenciesA big point I like to make about this game is the fact that it does have a premium currency, though it is only for vanity items and special weapons. Throughout the game you will never have premium items shoved in your face unless you choose to visit the shop yourself to see what there is.

Questing/ObjectivesQuesting can be fun and rewarding in this game as well. There is an in-depth main storyline which can lead to side-quests, but there are also tons of npc's around the world to get tasks from. In addition, there are quests to start you off in various skills, such as learning how to make weapons from ore, tailor clothes, farm a successful garden, or brew your own potions. The quests can lead you to new, interesting areas, and the big quests involve some depth and are not ridden with fetch objectives. All in all, I've enjoyed most of the quests, and the npc's who give them to you have character and are interesting to interact with.

The WorldThe world itself isn't the largest, though it is diverse and it is more expansive than I originally thought when starting out at the beginning of the game. Some quests lead you to  new regions outside the map of the main city and wilderness, but you can find cool areas simply by exploring. Be weary, though, and possibly bring a friend, for you may run into particularly aggressive high-level creatures during your ventures. Throughout the world, characters have connections between areas, and the general feel of the game is prevelant with npc's of different regions.

Group/Party PlayPlaying with a group is great. A couple of my friends and I decided to start this game together, and have chosen to focus on certain roles individually (I level up mining and weapon/armor crafting as well as being a melee warrior, one of us is an archer and levels in alchemy for potions, and another is our mage, leveling in magic with focus on healing and supplies us with food and charms). This system works great, as certain quests will lead you to group bosses, or raids, and it is a good idea to have backup on different roles. Also, you get an XP boost and can complete objectives simoultaneously to finish quests faster (defeating x/x enemies counts up together so you don't have to do it twice).

CommunityThe community is great as far as I can tell. Starting out a random guy gave me a couple premium currency for free in a trade, which I was greatful of, and me and another similarly leveled player focused on different tasks (me mining, him farming) and exchanged goods to help each other out after randomly meeting. The only thing detrimental is the fact that the amount of players playing this game is dwidling. I hope people in the community can help to kindle a bigger playerbase, because with more players there will be more opportunity to trade and sell services to one another which would make the whole game experience even better.

Final VerdictOverall this game is awesome. I've enjoyed grinding skills that I'm interested to supply my friends with better gear and sell to other players. The quests are enjoyable and the storyline has depth, so the whole experience can be quite immersive at times. There is opportunity to build your character whichever way you want, and group play adds to the experience. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes games like runescape as well as people who like fulfilling questlines or are just looking for a good f2p mmo.

reviewText:
Alright, there is a lot to say about this game. I will try to keep this as short as possible while still maintaining all the necessary information. I do not normally write reviews so bare with me on this. There is a reason I am choosing to write this review which you will see towards the end.

Now, let's begin with the game itself.

This game has been out for just barely more than a year. The staff behind this game have done an absolutely incredible job with quests, with the story line and overall game play.  Sure, there's some little buggy issues here and there, but it's an indie game that hasn't been out long. To expect perfection would be pretty ludicrous. Even EA puts out ♥♥♥♥ games and they're a billion dollar corporation.

Just like any MMORPG you have the basic classes and subclasses to character creation. Archer, Mage, Healer, Tank and then the subclasses like assassin, warrior ect. This system is pretty much universal but everyone has their own unique ways of doing it. I want to avoid comparing this to runescape, I know this is what everyone is doing. However the ONE thing I will say, is if you are looking for a runescape like game, this is your game.

The resource gathering on this game and the profession leveling can be a very painful grind at times. The Community in game is fantastic. You get the occasional jerks that just want to start ♥♥♥♥, but most everyone is very helpful and supportive.

The world... even now after 250 hours of game play on this game, I am finding places in this game I didn't even know existed. There's so much to explore, so much to do, there's an insane amount of side quests and story line quests.

Most importantly however, is the admin/customer support staff. There is none like this out there. You will not find a friendlier group of guys out there. If you have a problem and need a quick fix, find an online admin, or submit a ticket. Fast response times Monday through Friday and they legitimately seek to help you. The staff is what prompted me to write this review. I could not give this staff enough praise even if I wanted to. If they had the resources as a company like EA, Activision, SEGA, ect, the would would be the limit for these guys.

I WANT to rate this game based on potential. For a free to play, pay for benefits game, this game is incredible. It's not a pay to win game by any means. If I were to rate based on potential due to how young of a game this is, I would say 9/10. This game has that kind of potential.

However, to give this game a rating as it stands, I would give this game a 7/10. As much praise as I give this game, the only 2 complaints I have about it to drop it from an 8 to a 7 are the fact that the leveling really, really feels like a grind at times and there is somewhat of a lack of customization of armor/weapons. This may get fixed in the future though. There's just a slight lack of weapons/armor content is all.

This game is awesome, it's a lot of fun. Since its free to play there's nothing wrong with trying it out to see for yourself.

reviewText:
These are probably some of the worst graphics for a MMO. Avatar graphics look to be from 2001, and building and water graphics from 2004-2005. There is some lag, especially around extra busy areas.

And yet, this could be one of the best MMO's out there currently.

After having tried different MMO's out including LOTRO, SWTOR, and Spiral Knights, I can now look back at these and see where Eldevin has some of that or has corrected the mistakes these other popular MMO's have failed. Eldevin has a huge world to explore and discover, much like LOTRO. But with much better free roam possibilities. I just did a lvl 7 quest that had lvl 32 Ai.

SWTOR pushes you to choose a class. And theres no going back once its made. So your stuck between better powers or better storyline. SWTOR pretty much makes you need a team of players to fight boss's, and to be a higher level than the one your doing. SWTOR nags you about spending rl money on their game, going so far as to raise prices of the items you buy with credits, just for being a free-to-play player! Eldevin's quests are pretty simple and can be soloed pretty much, with a few tougher quests mixed in where you need a team, giving the game a great balance. I can be lvl 8 and take down a lvl 9 Ai. Might be a big fight and I lose extra HP, but least I dont get one-hit and die. Eldevin also lets you pretty much choose which side you want at a relaxing pace. Eventually you'll choose, but its more of just putting points into character traits. Now compare what I said about SWTOR, and Eldevin. You can easily see that Eldevin is the easier, more relaxed, and better able to get into than SWTOR.

Eldevin is also really a free-to-play game! As of when Im writing this, you can spend rl money for cosmetics, mounts, mount riding trait, potions, pets, and other knick-knacks. So no new player can come along, throw 100$ into Eldevin, and suddenly be the #1 player in-game, 2 hours later. Thats perhaps one of Eldevin's brightest points.

You can also earn reputation points with different factions in Eldevin. All these points do is show what type of quests you have done and lets you earn special vanity(cosmetic items) to wear in-game! That means you have complete freedom to choose which side(s) you choose to support! Though I have not yet found how to earn good reputation points with some of the factions yet, it would appear that they're out there somewhere.

Im still wearing the armour and helmet I recieved at level 4. Im now level 9. Most MMO's would drill you to change your gear every 2-3 ranks, with you dieing in battle every time, due to lack of armour stats. Maybe I have stronger weapons and thats why Im not having much trouble, but it seems the only limit to what gear your wearing is up to you making it, and your level.

I still have some mixed feelings about the professions, your healing ability, and the combat. The professions are a nusiance at best, yet the majority of new gear you can get for battle, so far, comes from being able to make your own gear(armoursmithing) which requires Mining. The rest, Im not sure about. The majority of players also agree in-game that this is annoying and perhaps the games worst point(next to the graphics in my book). I find woodcutting to be the useless profession as Im still yet to find whats the point of having logs and turning them into boards. Ill see as the game progress's for me.

The magical healing ability is, without a doubt, a very useful ally in-game. However, it heals such a tiny amount of your life, that its almost not worth the few second wait as you heal. Potions and eating food heals more in one use than this ability.

Combat is very nice! But maybe just a tad unbalanced. Archery is, no doubt, the strongest attack. I can weaken any enemy with 3 archery shots before it can even start its attack on me. They say melee is strong, but archery will end up being the best attack.

There is LOTS more I could say showing how great Eldevin is, but why should I? Just download it and see its awesomness yourself. It took me 4-5 minutes to download and took almost no MB. Hunted Cow Studios also has other computer games, including another MMO which has been out either 8 or 10 years depending where you look, and still seems to be going strong. So this game should be great. And with the promise of guilds coming, things will only look to get better. So install the game, enjoy the game, and see how MMO's should really be like! Especially if you played Free Realms or Star Wars: Clone Wars Adventures before they shutdown(oh terrible day!) then you will also love Eldevin.

reviewText:
*My play time is rather short as shown on Steam, but I have put about 300 hours into the game before writing this review. I'm no elite top-level player, but I have put enough into the game to have some opinions about it.

Ok, on with the review...

Eldevin is a fantasy MMORPG that does a lot of really good things, but these things aren't particularly new to the genre. And that's not necessarily a bad thing IMO.

Many compare it to other games like Runescape, and that is completely understandable. However, once you start playing, you will see some stark differences. It's approach to the genre is more of a themeparky style with PvE raids and traditional PvP game modes. Grab some loot from these instances and you'll then see the game's emphasis on a wide crafting system in which you make some nice gear. You have lots of quests to do, many of which are fetch-quests, but there are some nice cutscenes that propel the story forward. As either a sword-n-board tank, ranger, healer, warrior, mage, or hybrid build, you'll definitely have some quests to do.

reviewText:
50 hours in-game:

Eldevin is a addictive, slow-paced and story-driven MMORPG that is similar to Runescape 2 in many aspects.

You have a freedom of choice when it comes to using your talent points and building your character - You can pick any role and switch later on. When starting out, you are given a bunch of quests - In fact, more than you need to level up. Quests require a lot of travel and in order to do quests you need to have combat stats. It doesn't take long to level combat, but if you just keep doing combat you miss out on various loot and skilling (profession) opportunities - there being 14 different professions.

Professions can be tedious to level up because of slow animations (that you have to wait for), having too little inventory space, requiring a lot of travel and the materials costing too much at least early on. The sell price for most items is too low; you are constantly low on cash if you decide to use the materials you find for training professions. Only quests seem to reward a good amount of money at least at lower levels.

Crafting professions can require 2-4x more effort to level up than a gathering profession. What I mean by this is that you'll reach the max prospecting level 3 or 4 times in the time you max Jewelry, Armorsmithing and Weaponsmithing. I think this is rather stupid - it's just a time consuming grind to get to higher levels of each crafting profession for almost no benefit.

Even at higher levels, the time it takes to get to a level that matches your combat is better spent elsewhere. Instead of spending 10 hours to level 5 crafting levels, you could spend 10 hours questing and get 5 combat levels. Why should you do questing then? Because even if you get one crafting profession to your combat level, you'll only get that profession's specific equipment pieces; for example, a crafted heavy armor helmet to complete the set you just got from a dungeon, leaving rings/amulet/charm and weapons to be made with Jewelry and Weaponsmithing respectively. So yes, in short, the crafting professions feel useless and too tedious to level up.

Getting so little money from enemies and items early on creates problems because you need money for repair and training a profession. For example, from a level 10 quest you get 2 silver - it costs 2 silver to buy 4 butter (buy from npc) to go with your 8 ham (skinning/loot) and 4 garlic (farming) that you need to make 4 cooked hams at level 8 cooking. Yes, that's 2 silver or 1 quest to make 4 items.

reviewText:
HUGE EDIT

Okay I've played this game a bit more, learned about it & I've decided to change my rating because of this one fatal flaw that completely ruins the game.

YOU HAVE TO PAY TO RESPEC or wait 2 months!

Yes, that one little but HUGE flaw is making me not want to bother playing this game anymore.  Any game that emphasizes class customization makes you WANT to try out all the different specs that you can & this is just plain exploitation of their own system to FORCE you to pay money to try different things & for that I am saying NO.

If the game ever gets rid of this pure exploitive tactic then I may come back, until then I'm staying away.

REVIEW

Now before I start my review let me just say that a lot of people are comparing this game to Runescape & saying it's just a clone.  While this game & Runescape have a few things in common they are both completly different as a whole.  Now, with that said let's get on with the review.

GRAPHICS

Let me begin with the games graphics since it will be the first thing you see about the game.  The graphics aren't anything amazing or ground breaking but they do have their own unique feel.  It resembles oldschool RPG's like Morrowind & Neverwinter while pulling off it's own look in between.

There are some things I wish the game had graphics wise, however.  The game does have a day/night cycle but this feels like it's simply achieved by a slight contrast change.  Half the time you won't know if it's night or day unless you use the /time command which will bring up the current in game time.  Another thing I wish this game had would be a sun or a moon.  If you choose to bring the games camera down to OTS level you will notice the sky is bland & lifeless.  There is also no real time shading in the game.

Just because the graphics aren't great doesn't mean this game doesn't look good because it does.  It also feels alive in the scenery that you will see change depending on the time of day.  Some civilian NPC's have their own schedule & at evening to late night hours you will see the taverns start filling up with people.  They will even start having their own conversations while doing their daily activities that you can eavesdrop on.  The ones I've seen so far have been guards talking while on patrol & drunken men flirting with barmaidens.  This small feature alone brings out a lot more life to the game.

GAMEPLAY

The game can be played in 2 different ways.  Point & Click or WASD style.  So, if you prefer the top down camera point & click style ARPG you can play it that way.  If you prefer the OTS camera & walking with WASD you can do that as well.  You can seemlessly move between the 2 styles.  All & all it feels good & responsive.

The animations in the game are lacking, however.  They are simple, smooth & get the job done.  They aren't flashy like most MMO's are doing nowadays..  You won't see any moves that involve jumping around while attacking but you will see your character go into a solid stance.  When you attack it feels a little too quick.  Melee animations consist of quick swipes or jabs sometimes several per second that make it seem like your character is on speed or had too many energy drinks.

I do like the emotes a lot, though.  If you get your character drunk he will stumble around or vomit on himself.  It's pretty funny & probably worth playing the game to see that emote alone.

My only real complaint is no matter how much I push spacebar it never jumps.  :'(

CRAFTING

This game has a ton of crafting.  If you like games where you can spend hours upon hours of just crafting then you will probably enjoy this game.  I myself have already spent the majority of my game time doing nothing but crafting.  The best part is you can master all the crafts the game has to offer, so you will be busy for a while.

The game has weapon & armor smithing, cooking, leatherwork, jewelcraft, alchemy, tailoring, etc.  Every craft has it's own gathering profession. All of which are available to master.

CLASSES

This game utilizes a custom class system.  In short, you are what you want to be.  And I don't mean you are what you want within the games limits.  You are what you really want.  If you want to be a Battlemage in heavy plate you can do that.  If you want to be an archer with a big 2h weapon you can do that too.  This game's class system is possibly one of the coolest in any MMO I've played.

You earn points each level & you can put those points into Health, Mana, Melee, Range, Magic, & Crit/Accuraccy,  It's very easy to build a pure style or hybrid class.  If you plan on trying to do all 3 rolls you may have a harder time.  All equipment also increases these stats varying depending on what type of equipment you use.

There are also 6 Talent Trees.  Templar(Shield), Warrior (2H), Assassin (Dual Wield), Ranger, Mage & Prophet (Heals).  These trees each specialize in a specific weapon or spell type & gives passive/active abilities depending on which weapon/armor/spells you plan on using.

The best part about this game's class system is how you go about learning spells/abilities.  You simply buy a scroll from a trainer & learn it.  You keep the ability you purchase forever as well.  Respecs are just for points & talents.  The more powerful spells for each class are in the talent trees which you have to unlock by putting in points.

OVERALL

It's got a great oldschool vibe with a mix of modern day elements & manages to also do some things other games haven't done before.  If you're aching for an old school RPG or MMO experience without the subscription then you should check this one out.

I played this game outside of steam, I had a max leveled character with almost best gear and I am terribly sorry I played this game. Don't get me wrong, when I started playing, the game was doing fine, all it lacked was some balance and end game. But they never added end game content and just kept adding pay to win updates like buying gear upgrades.


I'll make this short, these are the bad points of the game, play if you can not mind:

-Pay to win, you can buy everything with real cash, and if you can't, you can buy it from other players by trading, this includes: Gold, Gear upgrading (which can't be done via in-game means), Bag space and others.
-No actual end game, you repeat 1 same dungeon over and over, after the 100th time it gets kinda boring, after 300th time you just kinda chit chat and make jokes with your teammates while wondering why aren't you using a bot because you're just clicking 1 or 2 spells
-Crafting is BORING, you know how you gather? Click on an iron ore, now wait 15 seconds, okay, now click on another iron ore. Oh wait, your inventory is full! How about you run 20 minutes back to the bank or pay for some inventory upgrades with real cash?
-Half of the updates are seasonal events, last one was gathering easter eggs, you walk around map and click on eggs, yes,  you have to do that 2000 times to get a key, which you can buy for 1 euro. That's how much these developers value your time, 1 euro is 10 hours of your time.
-The game lacks things like action house and guilds, and for some reason it's taking developers YEARS to make it. They also keep postponing the release by giving excuses.
-The game's population is very small, about 50 people per server online usually.
-Looking for dungeon group? Spam world chat or ask your friends. By friends I mean half the server, because if you add 30 people as friends, you have half the server there.
-PVP is dominated by 1 class alone, a mage healer hybrid can deal tons of damage and heal themselves, stomping over everyone else.
-Leveling is like any other game, the quests are a bit more interesting but not fun at all, you just kill 10 rats and then sometimes you get stuck with no quests, so you kill 500 rats to level just by that.


I have tried giving advice to the developers on the game forums for a few months now, I told them to stop with the pay to win updates, I told them how to make end game better, how to make leveling better, how to fix their game and they end up listening to none of what I said, or anyone else for that matter. I consider this game dead now, it will only get worse and I've lost all hope.


Conclusion: stay away unless you like playing an inferior, grindy, unfun, p2w game.

reviewText:
Tl;dr: Like Runescape, but better: faster combat, more fun & simple class building & crafting, better looking and playing world, better tho simple graphics and visual design, great music. Premium currency is not required to win and feels minimally intrusive: great for a free to play. I've played a ranged DPS-type character up to level 17.

Longer review:

I find a lot of MMOs boring but I did play lots of Runescape. This is similar in a lot of ways, but with a faster-paced WOW-like combat system, updated graphics, better music and a richer feeling world which is enhanced by said graphics and music.

Thematically they've made a really nice world - I have yet to find an enemy that seems out-of-place in the landscape, and the variety of enemies is pretty decent too. The map is a lot larger than it first looks, but personally it's nice having it divided into easy-to-navigate chunks. These chunks are thematically well done, there's variety in landscape and palettes which is pretty fun. The game feels pretty balanced over-all with how fast you progress and the various currencies you gain. The various groups/allegiences you can gain points with are pretty well thought-out, I think, and it's fun having multiple good-but-flawed factions which have decidedly different methods of dealing with things. The main storyline is servicable enough and works well enough with the presence of so many player characters.

I can't say much about PvP (it's not really my thing) other than that it exists. It's pretty easy to get in a group with people and the loot bidding/sharing system is pretty intuitive and simple, and basic etiquette is easy to grasp. There are no guilds, so everyone kind-of spontaneously forms groups. Also there is no marketplace, so people just trade in chat. This appeals to me, but others may enjoy the management, politics and economics that go with these features.

Dungeons can be done in groups or solo, both of which are fun, and can be attempted at 'story' or 'dungeon' modes, depending on how badly you want high level loot and a tough challenge. The big boss spawns are quite fun events to take part in. High-level players generally sheppard/protect lower level players on their way to the spawn location (usually through very high levelled aggro enemy areas), and everyone feels like they're kicking butt whatever their level. I've only played a ranged DPS so far, so I don't know if melee/spell-casting tank/DPS/healer is equally fun.

I also like that crafting here is fairly simple, with not that many tiers of ingredients. The game isn't very old and the level cap is around 45, but I like the minimal variety since too many components can make a game feel messy. There is some variety on each level with rare items you can craft from the ordinary components plus rare drops so I didn't find the simplicity boring.

Character-building:

You're human with not much customisation of appearance. Plenty of hair/skin colours and hair styles, not really much else. Very simple (like Runescape) graphics but decent within the limitations. Most of the game is best played zoomed out so this doesn't really matter.

There are six simple-enough classes so far, and you start aquiring abilities (attacks, spells, etc) in each, so you can figure out what you like before specialising. The six classes include 3 melee, 1 ranged, and 2 spell-casters, and they specialise in high-damage, high defense and healing. You're linked a basic guide on them to begin with, which is easily found on the wiki, which gives basic suggestions on which armor, weapons and attributes suit which classes. Talents (some abilities and passive upgrades) are divided up into classes, and since sticking to a class means getting higher-tier more impressive talents sooner, it's good to aim for one class early on when picking talents.

That said, characters aren't bound to any one class, and can equip whatever armor/weapons they like for their level. You'll do best specialising and upping your attributes (ie. weapon ability and max hp/mana etc.) to match your class/playing style. You get a free respec (get to redo all your attribute and talent points) at the start and every 60 days so switching classes is totally possible and easy enough. Good equipment is quite important.

Problems:

Since MMOs are quite grindy, good world-building appeals a lot to me. It's OK having to grind a little if the creatures and setting and crafting items all really suit each other, and different areas have distinct differences. For the most part, Eldevin is great at sticking to theme. The regular armor, some even dorky looking, fits well into the thematically well-made environments.

Most mounts I've seen are out of place in the setting, such as the easiest-to-obtain hover disk. Those that do suit the setting are, I guess, rarer since I don't see in-game all that often. But most I've seen seem not to fit the world very well at all. It's pretty easy to avoid using mounts and plenty of people you pass are on foot (especially in a less crowded server) so this is a minor issue. It still doesn't look good though. There is even a flying carpet which would be great if it looked like an actual rug that suits the setting. There are also quite a few vanity items that also don't look good, though these are less jarring than mounts. Also there are lots of vanity items that suit well enough (the Christmas event jumpers, for one), so it's not so bad.

I would love to be able to craft the clothes the civilians/villagers/city folk wear, maybe even other period-suiting clothes. That would be cool, even if they're very basic, hard to make and don't reap a profit given the price of their ingredients. Vanity items just for real money and/or lots of grinding in-game are great but they're already very impressive, so really mundane craftable vanity items shouldn't stop people buying the more impressive ones that go toward supporting the game.

Another note regarding the premium currency, I currently feel like I would spend some money on the game but am not really tempted by the offers. A fairly cheap deal for a small fraction of the items in one of the available packs would be nice, even if it is less value-for-money. The pickings aren't too bad, but I'll hold out until there's something I feel like I would really like to get and would enjoy using for the amount of money I would like to spend.

When i first started this game, I felt liek playing RuneScape classic. And I Loved it! The huge world, full of secrets, Great Crafting systems, a lot to do, a lot to waste your time and money on. reviewText:
It's not a bad MMO. It feels like a cross between Early WoW and Runescape.

The art is kind of terrible. It seems like half of models don't fit in with the world. and nearly all of the player models seem to be of significantly worse quality than the rest of the game. When I got Eldevin City, presumably the main hub in the game, nearly every higher leveled character i encountered looked like a ♥♥♥♥ing joke. I saw a guy riding around on a ♥♥♥♥ing disk like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed green goblin. Even the RIDING INSTRUCTOR is on a ♥♥♥♥ing flying disc. I saw people on broomsticks, giant goofy ♥♥♥ rabbit things attacking people in the street, and other random ♥♥♥ shit. If there's one thing that needs fixed about this game, it's the art style. Because there isn't one.

The UI is way to small, like WAAAAAAY too small. I'm not sure if there's a way to change that, but I didn't see one.

Most of the world seems empty. I think I figured out it's because there isn't a sky. It's just a gray overcast all the time. The game ran at an impressive 25 fps in the larger areas, presumably due to poor optimization. The story seemed horrendously cheesy. The player character didn't have hardly any personality at all.

It isn't THAT pay2win. It has a subscription service, similar to Runescape. Which isn't that bad. Subscribers get like 25% more experience and 25% more gold earned. Everyone is free to buy gold via a premium currency. I didn't bother looking into how much it gold cost.

I'd give this game a 6 out of 10. There are DEFINITELY better MMOs out there, and I'd reccomend you test the waters with this one before putting any money into this game.

reviewText:
Clearly, whoever decides to try out this game is not fueled by graphics.
That being said, Eldevin is a good option for those who seek quest-based MMOs with a developed crafting system.
What follows is a summary of some good and bad things about the game, becuase it has both.
• No auto-running. This has got to be the most annoying of all. You have to click to move, and the distance allowed is not very impressive, so you're pretty much clicking until you get to where you are going (and sometimes distances can be far).
• Good quest system. Everything is organized in your quest tab, you can take up as many quests as you want, and you normally find what you need and where you have to go. Some quests are even puzzle-like, which is refreshing.
• Good crafting system. You can craft all sorts of things (armor, weapons, potions, jewellery, food, etc.) with materials you collect from the game world (wood, metal ores, apples, limes, just to name a few).
NEGATIVE: leveling up a skill, say, your armorsmith skill takes FOREVER. At first, it's all nice and sweet. you gather the materials in a little bit, craft, and level up. Once you get to level 10, it really starts to slow down. And multiply that times 3 or 4 (because you will want to level up weapon and jewellery and maybe some other skill) and you are basically farming and crafting, instead of killing monsters or completing quests.
• The MAP: not very user friendly. At first you can't find anything and you get lost. Once you get acquainted with the game, you pretty much know where things are but the map doesn't really help that much.

Still, despite the fact that I mentioned more negative things than positive things (why am I playing thi again? lol), I recommend trying this game, at least.

reviewText:
I must say I am enjoying this more and more as I go along. I have even stopped my WoW subscription. So in short, I would definitely say you should at very least give this a go.

On the upside, there are so much content that you don't mind paying the few $/month to be a supporter. Which will give you those points that you need for smooth sailing. You can learn all the crafts and skills. So you can switch classes and take up professions that works with that class without losing progress on anything. The crafting system has got nice depth to it and still makes sense.

There are a lot of skills/spells for every class that allows you to build your character the way that fits your play style. You can even use skills from the other classes in your build.

Missions missions missions. There are so many. Dailies that for skills, missions for reputation, missions for craft rewards, side missions and main quests. So if you like missions you wont run out quick. Alternatively, if you don't, you can still dungeon grind your way through levels easy enough.

Finally, the community is nice and helpful. I have done tons of dungeon runs and never got called a noob or derp if I got stuck not knowing how to proceed when doing a dungeon the first time. People are friendly and helpful, which is rare these days.

I am likely missing a lot of things I wanted to add here, but I am rushing to get back in game.

There are a few hings that gets to me personally, like small stack sizes in inventory and a lot of back and forth running in quests, but I can also understand why this is so. It is not a pay2win, although it leans towards it. You CAN make it without paying, but it would be quite difficult.

reviewText: Great music, vibrant world and lovely, nostalgia inducing graphics. You create your own class as you play the game, instead of being forced to choose a class you know nothing about before you've even entered the game world. Crafting is fun to learn and doesn't feel like a useless afterthought. The structure of the world is similar to runescape - instead of wide, empty fields forcing you to spend half your time running, you start in a compact zone full buildings to enter, items you can collect, npcs to give you tasks and monsters to fight. This game feels like a cross between old school runescape and old school WoW. I just started but I can already tell I will love it.

Product received for free

TLDR; Look past the dated graphics for a highly recommended game.

A great game reminiscent of others like Fallen Earth and even perhaps Runescape, this rpg has a bit of everything with the great bonus of having a very friendly community. You'll see other comments stating the game has died, or that the player base is empty, but the few people around are the pinacle of a great MMO experience.

Within the first few hours of playing, I stumbled upon a few other people, all who came up to me and donated gold and gifts without even knowing who I was. There are no bots, it is not pay to win and the story is enjoyable and reasonably unique.

Definitely give this game a try (it's only a matter of MB to install!) if you are willing to look past some dated graphics and a small playerbase. Besides, each new player allows the game to grow, and the currently small online group means there is never any lag related to server-side issues.
